A black box in the car ?

US road planners are looking for a source of money to repair the decreasing high-way system , and believe to have found the solution in a small black box that can be found in the dashboard of each car .

The devices that record every kilometre spent and report information to the authorities are at the heart of a controversial attempt by Washington and federal planning offices to revise the outdated system for financing US roads .
The usually boring area of road planning has suddenly unleashed an intense debate with colourful alliances .

Libertarians have allied themselves with environmental groups and argue that the government can use the small boxes to record the kilometres driven – and possibly also where they have been driven – and then use the information to calculate tax costs .
The Tea Party is horrified .
The American Civil Rights Association ( ACLU ) is also deeply concerned and expresses a number of data protection concerns .
But , while Congress cannot agree on what to do , several states are no longer waiting .
They are currently examining how to switch over the next ten years to a system in which drivers pay per mile driven .
Thousands of drivers have already tested the tachographs , some of which are equipped with GPS monitoring .
That really is a must for our country .

“ It ’ s nothing we can only use , ” said Hasan Ikhrata , Managing Director of Southern California Assn. of Governments , who is planning to record the miles taken on all California drivers in the state from 2025 .
The way in which we pay those taxes will change .
The technology for this is there .
The initiative comes at a time when the Highway Trust Fund , financed from the taxes that Americans pay at the fence , is broken .
But America is no longer as big as it used to .
Cars use less petrol .
The state petrol tax of 18.4 cents per gallon ( less than 4 Eurocents per litre ) has not increased for 20 years .

“ The petrol tax is simply not future-proof , ” says Lee Munnich , an expert on transport legislation at the University of Minnesota .
Its state recently equipped 500 cars with tachographs to test a miles based payment system .
“ This is the most sensible alternative in the long term , ” he said .
Bureaucrats call it a miles based user fee .

It is not surprising that the idea is inspired by urban liberals , because the tax could , for example , be used to influence driving behaviour in such a way that congestion and climate-damaging exhaust gases are reduced .
California ’ s planners rely on the system for formulating policies aimed at achieving the federal state ’ s ambitious , legally anchored goals on climate change .
But the Republican Bill Shuster of Pennsylvania , Chairman of House Transportation Committee , has also stated that he sees the most viable long-term alternative .
The Reason Foundation ’ s free marketers are also inspired by the idea of allowing drivers to pay for the journey back .
“ This is not a tax disappearing in a black hole , ” explains Adrian Moore , Vice-President of Reason Guidelines .
People pay directly for what they get .
The movement is also supported by two former US transport ministers , who , in a report in 2011 , had called on Congress to move toward miles based reckoning .
The US Senate last year approved a $ 90 million pilot project that would have comprised 10,000 cars .
But the majority in the House prevented the push and responded to the concerns of rural MEPs representing people who often have to go to work or town on a daily basis .
Several states and major cities nonetheless move in that direction .
Oregon , which currently accrues 5,000 drivers for the country ’ s largest experiment , is the most dedicated .
These drivers will soon pay the mileage fee instead of the petroleum tax to the state .

In Nevada , where 50 volunteers were equipped recently , drivers were sceptical about the idea that the government could pursue any of their movements .

However , the devices they test are also interesting for road planners because they do not work with GPS and provide only limited information that is regularly uploaded via modem .
